questions.text: A newly married woman was prescribed MALA-N at a primary health center. What is its composition?
questions.solution:
Mala-N is a combined oral contraceptive containing 0.15 mg levonorgestrel (LNG) and 0.03 mg ethinyl estradiol.

It is supplied free of cost through all primary health centers, urban family welfare centers, etc.

Each strip of Mala-N contains 21 hormonal tablets and 7 nonhormonal tablets (iron tablets).

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient presents with a history of chronic fatigue. He has no significant past medical or surgical history and he is on a strict vegan diet. His peripheral smear is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario along with the image is highly suggestive of megaloblastic anemia. In the given image, the peripheral smear shows cabot rings and basophilic stippling.

Megaloblastic anemia is a type of macrocytic anemia with impaired nucleic acid metabolism. Nuclear maturation lags behind cytoplasmic maturation. The causes include

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Folate deficiency
  • Drugs (Methotrexate)

In this stem, the likely cause is vitamin B12 deficiency as the patient is a strict vegan. Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Other causes of B12 deficiency includes

  • Malabsorption (Pernicious anemia)
  • Total or partial gastrectomy
  • Ileal resection
  • Tropical sprue

Clinical features of cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency (megaloblastic anemia) include:

  • Anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation
  • Oral manifestations: glossitis, angular cheilosis
  • Mild fever in more severely anemic patients
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Bruising (thrombocytopenia) and infections (low leucocyte count)
  • Complications in pregnancy: recurrent fetal loss and neural tube defects
  • Cardiovascular disease: cerebrovascular, peripheral vascular, and coronary heart disease with deep vein thrombosis
  • Neurologic manifestations: Bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord (SACDSC). Seen in only B12 deficiency.
  • Psychiatric disturbances

The peripheral smear shows oval macrocytes, anisocytosis, and hypersegmented neutrophils (more than 5 nuclear lobes).

Other features of ineffective erythropoiesis seen in megaloblastic anemias include:

  • Howell-Jolly bodies: Nuclear remnants within red cells that are usually single, round, dark purple-red in color, and peripheral in location.

 

  • Basophilic stippling: Blue granules of various sizes dispersed throughout the cytoplasm of the red cell, they represent ribosomal precipitates.
  • Cabot rings: Red cell inclusions appearing as fine, purple filamentous loops or figures of eight forms, presumed to be remnants of mitotic spindles.

The image below shows basophilic stippling and Cabot rings:

questions.text: Water lily sign is seen in infection due to _____
questions.solution:
Water lily sign is seen in hydatid cyst, an infection due to Echinococcus granulosus.

Hydatid Cyst is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species (dog tapeworm). Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus. Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, but humans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since there is no human-to-human transmission.

The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is mainly asymptomatic until complications occur. The most common presenting symp­toms are abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and vomiting. The most frequent sign is hepatomegaly.

The water-lily sign is seen in hydatid infections when there is detachment of the endocyst membrane, resulting in floating membranes within the pericyst that mimic the appearance of a water lily, on USG.

questions.text:
A patient with severe persistent asthma continues to have symptoms despite being on high-dose ICS-LABA therapy. Which of the following is a leukotriene receptor antagonist, appropriate as an add-on therapy for this patient?

ICS-LABA : Inhaled corticosteroids - Long acting bronchodilators
questions.solution:
Zafirlukast can be used as an add-on therapy in this patient.

Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. They are competitive antagonists of the cysLT1 receptors. These drugs act by: 

  • Decreasing bronchoconstriction
  • Reducing airway mucus secretion
  • Decreasing vascular permeability and
  • Reducing eosinophil chemotaxis 

Leukotriene modifiers are less effective than inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) in controlling asthma. They are used as add-on therapy in some patients whose asthma is not controlled with low doses of ICS.

Option A: Dupilumab is an interleukin-4 receptor antagonist used in severe asthma. 

Option B: Roflumilast is a PDE-4 selective inhibitor used in the treatment of COPD.

Option D: Zileuton is a lipoxygenase inhibitor that can be used in the treatment of asthma.

questions.text: Which among the following is an electrolyte abnormality that is not observed in CRF (chronic renal failure)?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia is not commonly seen in chronic renal failure.

Electrolyte abnormalities in chronic renal failure are:

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypermagnesemia

*Note :
Hyponatremia and hypokalemia although not commonly seen in CKD patients can occur occasionally. Hypokalemia is not common in CKD and usually reflects markedly reduced dietary potassium intake, especially in association with excessive diuretic therapy or concurrent GI losses.

questions.text: Among the given women, the best candidate for the role of accredited social health activist (ASHA) is a 25–45-year-old woman who is ______.

choices.text: Unmarried with education up to the 10th standard
Married with education up to the 5th standard
Unmarried with education up to the 5th standard
A widow with education up to the 10th standard

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option D, woman who is a widow with education up to the 10th standard.

An ASHA is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with a formal education of at least up to 8th grade. She should preferably be in the age group of 25 to 45 years (married/divorced/widow) and have qualities such as good communication skills and leadership skills. The general norm of selection recommends having one ASHA for 1000 population, but in tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.

 Roles of ASHA:

  • To create awareness and provide information to the community on determinants of health such as nutrition, basic sanitation, and hygienic practices
  • To counsel women on birth preparedness, the importance of safe delivery, breast-feeding and complementary feeding, immunization, and contraception
  • To counsel women on the prevention of common infections including reproductive tract infection/sexually transmitted infection 
  • To mobilize the community and help them in accessing health and health-related services.
  • To arrange and escort pregnant women and children requiring treatment/admission to the nearest pre-identified health facility
  • To inform sub-center/primary health center about the births and deaths in her village and any unusual health problems/disease outbreaks in the community
  • To promote the construction of household toilets under the total sanitation campaign

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, bluish discoloration was present over the left 9th and 10th rib area. On asking the patient to take a deep breath, he winced due to pain in the left shoulder region.  Identify the most likely sign elicited here.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette mentions pain over the left shoulder tip on inspiration. This is known as Kehr's sign, seen in splenic trauma.

Blunt trauma to the spleen results in torsion of short gastric vessels in the gastrosplenic ligament leading to subphrenic hematoma. The irritation at the left hemidiaphragm by subphrenic hematoma leads to positive Kehr's sign.

The initial investigation for abdominal injury in patients who are hemodynamically unstable is FAST (focused assessment with sonography in trauma) to explore for free fluid.

In all hemodynamically stable patients, CT is the investigation of choice for identifying and characterizing splenic injuries.

Other options:

Option A- Courvoisier's sign is palpable gall bladder in the presence of jaundice due to periampullary carcinoma.

Option B- Cullen's sign is dark bluish discoloration around the umbilicus due to hemoperitoneum.

Option C- Ballance sign is a sign of splenic injury. Persistent dullness on the left side of the abdomen due to early coagulation of blood from the spleen is a positive sign. Shifting dullness can be present on the right side.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not cause hyperpigmentation as an adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Beta-blockers do not cause hyperpigmentation.

Drugs causing hyper melanosis:

  • Amiodarone
  • Tetracyclines
  • Chloroquine
  • Clofazimine
  • Phenytoin
  • Cytotoxic drugs like busulfan, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, etc.
  • Psychotropic drugs (e.g., trifluoperazine, imipramine)

questions.text: A patient with Crohn's disease has multiple skip lesions in the intestine. Surgical resection of damaged areas is being planned. Removal of which part will cause steatorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Ileal resection may lead to steatorrhoea.

The ileum is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts. Following resection of the ileum, the loss of bile salts increases and is not met by an increase in synthesis. Depletion of the bile salt pool results in fat malabsorption that presents with steatorrhea.

questions.text: A young male patient with hereditary hemochromatosis has been started on weekly phlebotomy. All of the following features will improve with this treatment except:
questions.solution:
In hemochromatosis, removal of excess iron through phlebotomy has no effect on arthropathy and hypogonadism.

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused due to mutation in the HFE gene on chromosome 6, leading to excessive iron absorption.  Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. 

The manifestations of classic hemochromatosis include hepatomegaly, abdominal pain, abnormal skin pigmentation mainly in sun-exposed areas, defective glucose homeostasis or diabetes mellitus, cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias, cardiomyopathy), and atypical arthritis. The testes may be small and atrophic resulting in reduced gonadotropin and testosterone levels.

It is managed by weekly or twice weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL. Chelating agents like subcutaneous deferoxamine, oral deferasirox are effective.

questions.text: In the following flowchart representing the natural history of disease, the duration between points A to B is called?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the final critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point C in the image).

This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. The final critical point (point B in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called lead time.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

questions.text: An elderly patient in the gynecology ward was diagnosed with urge incontinence. What is the etiology of this condition?

choices.text: Pelvic mass in pouch of Doughlas

questions.solution:
A patient who suffers from urge incontinence suffers from detrusor instability.

The patient experiences an involuntary escape of urine with an urge to urinate. It occurs due to detrusor muscle overactivity or detrusor instability. It is seen more commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity, decreased sensation, and central nervous system (CNS) inhibition.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with bilateral adnexal masses and ascites. Histopathological examination of the resected specimen shows sheets of mucin-producing signet-ring cells. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis with the above clinical interpretation is metastatic signet-ring carcinoma called Krukenberg tumor.

Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic ovarian malignancy with the primary site is in the gastrointestinal tract or breast. It is often bilateral. Primary sites include the stomach (70%); carcinoma of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma). Numerous signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. Signet ring cells are mucin-producing cells with the appearance of a signet ring often originating from the gastric mucosa.

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Kruckenberg tumor.

questions.text: Active transport is mediated by which one of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
In active transport, the energy is provided almost exclusively by the hydrolysis of ATP. Hence active transport is mediated by ATPases (eg. Na+-K+-ATPase), enzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of ATP.

PRIMARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT SECONDARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT
Requires direct input of metabolic energy in the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)   The transport of two or more solutes is coupled and metabolic energy is provided  indirectly from the Na+ gradient that is maintained across cell membranes by Na+-K+-ATPase pump

a) Na+-K+-ATPase or sodium potassium pump

b) Ca2+ -ATPase

c) H+-ATPase or proton pump d)      H+-K+-ATPase

a) Na+- glucose cotransport (SGLT)

b) Na+-Ca2+ counter transport

Related Pearl: Transport across the cell membrane

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Type Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Primary active transport Secondary active transport Cotransport Secondary active transport Countertransport
Electrochemical gradient Downhill Downhill Uphill Uphill Uphill
Carrier mediated No Yes Yes Yes Yes
Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

 		 -- -- Inhibits Inhibits  Inhibits

questions.text:
The device shown in the image given below is used in.

HDR - High dose rate
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a remote afterloader. Remote afterloading is related to brachytherapy.

Brachytherapy is a method of treatment in which sealed radioactive sources are used to deliver radiation at a short distance by interstitial, intracavitary, or surface application.

The following isotopes are used in brachytherapy:

  • I-125 and Iridium-192 - used in low dose rate (LDR) brachytherapy. 
  • Cobalt-60 - is used for high dose rate (HDR) brachytherapy.

Afterloading is the process of placing the radioactive material into the target region. This is either done manually by the oncologist, or by using remote afterloading devices.

Remote afterloading devices enable us to eliminate direct contact with radioactive sources while administration. It provides protection from radiation exposure to healthcare professionals by securing the radiation source in a shielded safe manner.

questions.text: While assessing the Apgar score of newborns, you would assess and score all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Respiratory effort, not rate is a component of the Apgar score.

The Apgar score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn's condition using the 5 parameters explained below. It is performed at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth. The components of the Apgar score are:

  • Color (A, appearance)
  • Heart rate (P, pulse)
  • Response to a catheter in nostril (G, grimace)
  • Muscle tone (A, activity)
  • Respiratory effort (R)

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A young man was rushed to the casualty with multiple rib fractures. On examination, you notice a paradoxical movement of the chest, and the patient is diagnosed with respiratory failure. How would you manage him?

choices.text: Internal operative fixation of the fractures segments

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of flail chest with respiratory failure. Management of this condition is IPPV (intermittent positive pressure ventilation).

A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage. This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures i.e., 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places. 

The blunt force required to disrupt the integrity of the thoracic cage typically produces an underlying pulmonary contusion as well.

On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards, and therefore, less air moves into the lungs. On expiration, the segment moves outwards. This is known as paradoxical respiration.

The diagnosis is made clinically, not by radiography. To confirm, the paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment can be observed for several respiratory cycles and during coughing.

Voluntary splinting as a result of pain, mechanically impaired chest wall movement, and the associated lung contusion are all causes of hypoxia and respiratory failure. The patient is also at high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax.

Treatment:

  • Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided.
  • Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia, and physiotherapy.
  • IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for patients developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

Treatment algorithm of treatment of flail chest with respiratory failure:

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as 'A' in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution: The structure marked as 'A' in the CT thorax is the superior vena cava.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a gradually progressing swelling and pain for 6 months over the upper tibia. His radiographic image is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiographic image findings are most suggestive of Brodie's abscess.

A Brodie abscess is a localized subacute osteomyelitis that occurs in the long bones of lower extremities in young patients. 

All of the given conditions may present with a history of swelling and pain. However, the differentiating features of each of the given conditions are as follows:

Condition Age group Radiographic findings
Brodie's abscess

Children, adolescents

 Lytic lesion with dense sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Osteosarcoma Children, adolescents and seventh decade Periosteal reaction leading to sunray appearance and Codman triangle
Osteoclastoma 20-40 years Lytic lesion with thin sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Ewing's sarcoma 10-20 years Periosteal reaction leading to onion peel appearance

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency after being trapped in a landslide for 3-4 hours. He has multiple rib fractures, pneumothorax, hemothorax, and lab findings of elevated creatinine, creatine phosphokinase, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and hypocalcemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of prolonged entrapment, clinical features, and laboratory findings are all suggestive of crush syndrome. 

Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or machinery) and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. 

Crush syndrome can result in a systemic reaction due to tissue necrosis. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants that escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

Clinical features:

  • The affected limb is pulseless, red, and swollen
  • In some cases, sensation and muscle power may be lost.

Management of crush syndrome

  • Encouraging high urine flow, along with alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate to prevent precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules.
  • Renal hemofiltration if there is oliguria or renal failure.
  • If compartment syndrome is confirmed, then fasciotomy is performed.
  • Radical excision of necrosed muscle to avoid sepsis.
  • Aggressive management of the open wound.

Other options:

Option A: Fat embolism is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after a fracture of the long bone or other major trauma. It is usually seen 2-3 days following the injury. Clinical features include tachycardia, rise in temperature, breathlessness, and mild mental confusion. 

Option C: Hemorrhagic shock is the most common cause of shock in surgical or trauma patients. Here the patient presents with agitation, cold clammy extremities, hypotension, tachycardia, and weak peripheral pulses. Acidosis and elevated lactate levels may be seen due to hypoperfusion of tissues.

Option D: Acute compartment syndrome refers to an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis. It can occur following fractures(commonly) or soft tissue injuries and is a localized condition involving the affected limb. The clinical features include pain, paraesthesia, pallor, paralysis, and pulselessness. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the intracompartmental pressures.

questions.text: A child hailing from China has been diagnosed with Keshan disease. The child is most likely suffering from deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Keshan disease is due to a deficiency of selenium.

Selenium is an important trace element which is a part of the 21st amino acid Selenocysteine. There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as :

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant which complements the role of Vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy is the characteristic feature, but it may also result in congestive cardiac failure, cardiomegaly, and fulminant cardiogenic shock. It is associated with tumorigenesis (increased risk of progression to metaplasia) and atherosclerosis.

Related Pearl: Metals as cofactors and prosthetic groups in enzymes

Metal  Enzymes
Zinc

Carboxypeptidase

Alcohol dehydrogenase

Alkaline phosphatase

ALA dehydratase

Lactate dehydrogenase

Tyrosinase

Lysyl oxidase

Amino acid oxidase
Molybdenum

Xanthine oxidase

Sulfite oxidase
Manganese

Mitochondrial superoxide dismutase

Hexokinase

Phosphofructokinase

Iron Succinate Dehydrogenase

questions.text: Under McNaughten's rule, which of the following criteria is not valid to clear a mentally unsound person of all responsibility?

choices.text: Psychiatric illness while committing the crime
Inability to understand that the act is wrong

questions.solution:
The criterion of the presence of uncontrollable impulse is not included in McNaughten's rule. Therefore, it is not a valid criterion to clear a mentally unsound person of all criminal responsibility.

McNaughten's rule is followed by the British Courts of law to examine the liability of a mentally unsound person who has committed a crime. Sec. 84 IPC (BNS Section 22) is the Indian adaptation of this rule. 

McNaughten's rule forms the basis of the legal test of insanity/the 'right or wrong' test. It states that a mentally unsound person is cleared of all criminal responsibility for the crime committed if the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of evidence of psychiatric illness.
  • Existence of psychiatric illness at the time of the commission of the crime.
  • Psychiatric illness is of such a degree that the person does not have the ability to understand the wrongness of the act, i.e., impaired intellectual ability. 

McNaughten's rule decides a person's soundness of mind based on the presence or absence of intellectual ability. However, it fails to consider any impairments in the person's emotional state or the presence of any uncontrollable/ irresistible impulses while committing the act.

questions.text: A young male patient who had witnessed a terrorist attack has been experiencing frequent intrusive flashbacks and nightmares about the incident. He avoids the places that remind him of it.  He is significantly distressed, has difficulty falling asleep, and frequently feels anxious for the last 6 months. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with re-experiences (flashbacks and nightmares), avoidance of the stimuli associated with the attacks, and hyperarousal (impaired sleep and anxiety) for more than one month are suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

PTSD is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse. 

The predisposing factors for this condition include:

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
  • Hyperarousal 
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event

The duration of these symptoms should be > 1 month to label it as PTSD.

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. SSRIs may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to stressful situations like financial issues, medical illnesses, or relation­ship problems that develop within 3 months of the stressor. The stressor in adjustment disorder can be of any severity. In adjustment disorder, the individual does not experience intrusive symptoms like flashbacks and nightmares, hyperarousal symptoms, and avoidance symptoms.

Option B: Acute stress disorder presents with the same symptoms as PTSD, but the symptoms usually occur immediately after the trauma and persist for a period of 3 days to upto 1 month after the trauma.

Option C: Persistent complex bereavement disorder occurs after the death of a loved one. Since the death, for 12 months or more, the individual may experience persistent yearning/longing for the deceased, intense sorrow, and emotional pain, preoccupation with the deceased, and the circumstances of the death. 

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of Trauma and Stress related disorder

 
PTSD
Adjustment disorder
Bereavement
Stressor
Extreme traumatic events like rape or accident
Financial/ Illness/ Relationship issues
Death of a loved one
Time
Symptoms
develop within 6 months and persist more than 1 month
Symptoms
develop within 3 months and resolve in 6 months if stressor eliminated
Symptoms develop within 2 months and resolve within 2 months
Symptoms
Flashbacks and nightmares
Mostly depressive and anxiety
Mostly depressive

questions.text: Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes do not include
questions.solution:
The submandibular group of lymph nodes is not included as a part of Waldeyer’s ring.

Scattered throughout the pharynx in its subepithelial layer is the lymphoid tissue which is aggregated at places to form masses, collectively called Waldeyer’s ring.

The masses are:

  • Nasopharyngeal tonsil or the adenoids
  • Palatine tonsils or simply the tonsils
  • Lingual tonsil
  • Tubal tonsils (in fossa of Rosenmüller)
  • Lateral pharyngeal bands
  • Nodules (in posterior pharyngeal wall)

questions.text: Which of the following is defined as loss of eyelashes?
questions.solution:
Madarosis is the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows.

  • Loss of eyebrows is seen in leprosy and myxedema.
  • Loss of eyelashes is seen in chronic blepharitis.

 

Option A: Tylosis is a thickening of the tarsal border of the eyelid. 

Option C: Trichiasis is an inward misdirection of cilia, with the normal position of the lid margin.

Option D: Distichiasis is the presence of a double row of eyelashes.

questions.text: A specimen of the posterior surface of the larynx is kept in an anatomy practical exam and a structure is marked with red. What would be the action of the structure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the posterior view of the larynx and the marked muscle is the posterior cricoarytenoid. Its action is to abduct the vocal cords and open the glottis. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is identified by its origin from the posterior surface of the cricoid. 

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle arises from the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina and is attached to the upper and posterior surfaces of the muscular processes of the ipsilateral arytenoids. It is innervated by a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. They are active in the production of unvoiced sounds.

The image below shows the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: An air conditioner technician presents with diarrhea, high fever, chest pain, and dyspnea. Chest radiograph showed pleural effusion and patchy pulmonary infiltrates. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of gram-negative bacilli point toward the diagnosis of legionnaire's disease. Macrolides such as Azithromycin is the drug of choice for this condition.

Legionnaire’s disease is caused by Legionella pneumophila. They are found in lakes, streams, and other water bodies. Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditioners, humidifiers, nebulizers, etc.

It is mostly asymptomatic under the age of 55 years. Infection is usually severe in immunocompromised patients. It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhea, and delirium. On chest x-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. 

A milder form of a clinical syndrome known as Pontiac fever, which is usually self-limiting and only has mild symptoms of fever, myalgia, and headache.

Microscopy of the sputum samples shows numerous leucocytes without any organism. Gram staining of the sterile sites like pleural fluid and lung tissues show faint gram-negative bacilli. They require a counterstain of basic fuschin as safranin stains the bacteria very poorly. They are a group of fastidious, aerobic gram-negative bacteria. They can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar.

Diagnosis is established with the help of direct fluorescent antibody tests and BCYE culture specimens. Urine antigen tests and molecular assays may also be used.

The below image shows the Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test.

As L. pneumophila is an intracellular pathogen, antibiotics that reach high intracellular concentrations must be used.

Macrolides and quinolones are the antibiotics of choice and are effective as monotherapy. Alternatively, agents like doxycycline may also be used. B-lactams, monobactams, and aminoglycosides are not considered to be effective. The total duration of therapy is 10-14 days for immunocompetent hosts and up to 3 weeks for immunosuppressed patients.

questions.text:
Given below is the procedure done under 'Nalgonda technique'. What is the purpose of this technique?
Add lime + alum
↓
Flocculation
↓
Sedimentation
↓
Filtration

choices.text: Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal
Air floatation of grains to remove ergot

questions.solution:
Nalgonda technique is used for defluoridation of water which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana(Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu. 

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5mg/L)
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6mg/L) 
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10mg/L)

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

The given images show dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification), respectively:

 

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age

Other options:

Superchlorination of water is the addition of large amounts of chlorine to the water, for disinfection. The excess is later removed. It is done for heavily polluted water with fluctuating quality.

Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal is done for Lathyrism. The toxin beta oxalyl amino alanine in its crystalline form is water-soluble. The pulse is soaked in boiling water for 2 hours and the water is drained off completely. It is then washed with clean water and dried. 

Air floatation of grains is done to remove ergot, which is a field fungus. It can be removed by floating the grains in 20% saltwater, air floatation, or hand picking.

questions.text: Analgesia produced by opioids is mediated by which receptor?
questions.solution:
Analgesia produced by opioids is mediated by µ, k, and δ receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following is Sims curette?
questions.solution:
The instrument marked as 1 in the image is Sims curette. 

It is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.

It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of uterine tissue.

 The image above shows the trolley with various instruments:

  1. Sims uterine curette
  2. Hegar dilator
  3. Sims uterine sound
  4. Karman's cannula - It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula
  6. Rubin's cannula 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG
